Fields.DialogueText: Wicher! What's with all of these lifeboats? The deck's cluttered with them!
I just thought that I would procure some extras to account for the other things we'll need to save, if I sink.
What do you – oh, you mean the library?
Tak. Exactly. They can't swim – or be exposed to water at all, in fact.
Well, that's kind of the risk you take when you start a library at sea.
I know, but it's not like the land is much safer right now. I just want to make sure that I can protect both them and everyone on board.

Fields.MenuText: Lifeboats aren't of much use if you can't get them lowered.
Maybe we could make special capsules to store the books in.
We might have to leave a few of the books behind. We can keep their memory, but lives matter more.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I guess I'll have to limit the number just so we can evacuate accordingly if we need to.
That might work, but they would need to float as well. Still, it's a project I can work on.
I know. If necessary, I'll sacrifice them to save everybody. But I want to at least make the effort to preserve these links to the past as well.
In any case, I hope that we never need to use these things. Because we'd never be able to get everyone on them.
What do you mean? There should be enough for everybody now.
There's enough for all the humans. But what about you, Wicher?
You're right - but that's something I may have to face one way or another someday. Until then, I will embrace life, for as long as possible.
Good. I couldn't stand to lose... Hey, I think there are some Morganas on the way.
Thankfully they can't use lifeboats either.
@BATTLE
Wicher, I think we might have sprung a leak or something!
What makes you think that, Kapitan? Everything seems fine from my end.
I just saw a bunch of water washing along the hall over there.
Oh, I'm sorry. That must be just some spillage from the waterfall.
Ah, that makes sense. As long as you're more careful now....
It's not a natural one – it's one I managed to set up with some hydraulics.
Interesting, but what's it for?
It's to provide an extra source of power onboard. I got the inspiration from the mills at Narva. The water runs against a few wheels further down to crank up a few watts.

Fields.MenuText: Won't we use up more energy getting the water up there?
The waterfall is kind of pretty.
Please be more careful with the water. We don't want to get too much power by electrocuting something.

Fields.DialogueText: That's an issue, I admit, but I think I found a way to get it up there without too much hassle. It won't work in all cases, but at least it's something.
Thank you. Dziekuje ci. That's another reason why I did this. I thought it would be really nice little oasis.
Right! I'll take the necessary precautions, right away.
It's interesting how the waterfall embodies both nature's wildness and human industriousness.
That is the spirit of human ingenuity. We can, slowly but surely, find the keys to understanding and maintaining the world.
Or the means to destroy it.
No ba - that, too. We will just have to be careful how we use our knowledge, then.
You're right. Besides, we need some destructive power if we want to stop the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Wait. What?
What are you making there, Wicher? Sausage or fish?
Nie, something else entirely – malasadas.
Interesting. They're not Polish, are they?
No ba. It's actually from Madeira.
I see. What gave you the idea to make it?
Well, we have had an excess in sugar of late, and they make these on the islands to get rid of food for Lent.
Good thinking – just as long as you didn't use it all up.
Don't worry. Plus... I wanted to see if I could make my own version like the others.
What do you mean?
Sailors have traveled from Madeira all over the world. As a result, there are unique versions of malasadas everywhere as far away as Hawaii.
Oh, I get it – you want to adapt one for Poland.
Tak - and for out here as well. We are somewhat of our own land, traveling the waters together.

Fields.MenuText: In that case, I wonder what traditions of ours will get spread across the globe as well.
Why not make malasadas of both kinds – for here and for Poland?
This fleet is sort of a cultural nexus in itself, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: Not the smoking, I pray!
That could work. I'll see what I can whip up.
Yes. That's part of what gave me the idea to do this.
Well, they certainly look tasty.
Thank you. They should be just about done.
Say, can they last a while?
Of course. Why do you ask?
Because we'll need to take a short recess first to eliminate some hungry predators.
@BATTLE
Daisy, daisy, I go crazy over the Kapitan's...
Hi, Wicher!
Wah! Careful, Kapitan! You startled me, and I almost crashed.
Sorry about that. You need to be careful riding a bike around the halls, though. Is this really the best place for a bicycle?
Well, I have never seen a bad place for one. From France to up in the northern peninsula, bicycles can be quite useful for moving about.
I can see that. You're pretty good at it.
Dziekuje ci - you're very kind! I liked to practice at each of the stops on my tour.
Still, it's kind of cramped in here for biking.
You're probably right. But what can I do?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you could recycle the parts for some kind of pulley.
Now that I know about your dilemma, I could see about making a small route for you on board. It won't be much, but it's something.
Why don't you hang onto it for when we have shore leave?

Fields.DialogueText: That's not a bad idea, but I kind of have an attachment to this old baby.
Thank you, Kapitan. That really makes me happy.
Yes, it would be like what I did during my past stops. What a great idea!
Anyway, you can try biking around some more, but you'll need to be careful. Pedal more slowly.
Okay, sure. And here I got this so I could respond to Morganas more speedily.
Say, I wanted to ask, what were you singing just before –?
And look at that, here's one now! Let's go!
@BATTLE
La de da! Oh, hello there, Kapitan.
Hello, Wicher. Where are you off to?
Isn't it obvious? I am going to go swimming.
Wicher, we're way out in the ocean. It's kind of cold and dangerous to go swimming.
Are you kidding? The water is lovely around here. Compared to Gdynia, the water out here is like a hot bath.
I'll take your word for it.
No ba! We've set up a very nice resort area around the beaches and coast. Well, did – I don't know what it's like at the moment.
Try not to worry too much about that.
Thank you. It's just that I keep feeling homesick. That's why I wanted to go for a swim, so I could feel like I was back there. But it isn't the same.

Fields.MenuText: Every place has its own positive and negative aspects. It may be different, but it can still be fun.
I think I'd like to visit one of the resorts there with you, one day.
You can still keep your memories alive and use them to make something new.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. Here isn't that bad either. Maybe enough to attract people...
I know that you would enjoy it!
Yes, I could.
How about I join you? The more the merrier, after all.
Great! Thank you.
Don't mention it. But we should probably clear out the local water hazards first.
@BATTLE
Very wise.
I hope I'm not speaking from a position of total ignorance here, but... Gdynia's beaches are traditionally fairly popular, aren't they?
What's cooking this time?
Limpets.
Heh, good one. You can come up with great jokes sometimes. Now, really, what is it?
Lapas.
Interesting. What is in there?
Limpets.
Wait, really?
Tak. It's another popular dish from Madeira.
I'm surprised there's any meat in those bony little things.
They are quite sturdy, aren't they? Which is why this will help us reduce the amount clinging to my hide!

Fields.MenuText: You certainly like all sorts of seafood.
I can't wait to taste it. You're a marvelous cook.
You know, limpets remind me of you – slow but durable.

Fields.DialogueText: I sure do! I love all sorts of things – and the sea is one of the most diverse places of them all.
Kapitan, you're making me blush.
Thank you. I do feel a sense of camaraderie with them, but not enough to keep them out of the cooking pot, though.
I guess there are all sorts of things that you can make work as edible food.
Yes, you just have to put your mind to it, and your sense of creativity will come up with something.
Is there anything you cannot cook?
I'd have to say Morganas – can't figure out how to prepare them, no matter how much I try.
Don't feel bad. In their case, it's probably best to overcook them.
Tak - quite right. Now let's crack a few of those goons into pieces.
@BATTLE
Hiyaa!
Taking karate classes now? You sure like to try new things.
Well, I have another motivation for it. I want this to be as easy as a piece of cake.
Well, yeah, we all want to do our best at everything.
Nie, nie – I meant so that I could cut a piece of cake like a board.
Can't you just use a fork or knife?
Yes, but the traditional Bolo de mel of Madeira is supposed to be split by hand.
Oh, that's... odd.
Tak. And I have never been able to master it. So, I felt that this could help.

Fields.MenuText: Plus, it gives you more self-defense training.
You can always try to just cut it your own way.
Well, you can always split the task – bake the cake and then have someone else cut it.

Fields.DialogueText: That, too. We need every little advantage we can take against the Morganas and others.
I know, and I might do that. Still, I like to respect local customs, and it's a way for me to try new things.
Good point – teamwork always comes in handy. The question is, do we know anyone who can cut that way?
Well, you seem to be making good progress with the boards there.
Mm. I'm a little worried that it will splatter if I try it on the cake.
You just need to try more variety.
Oh, look! Here comes something that I can practice cutting, now.
@BATTLE
Now let's see, how do you do this? I didn't expect this to be easy, but I didn't expect it to be so difficult, either.
What's with all of that stone here, Wicher?
Kapitan - witaj! I was trying to make a sculpture.
You're trying to sculpt?
Mm-hm. I got inspired by the works of Emil Jerichau.
I see. How are things coming along?
Okay, but I'm having some trouble getting the hang of things.
Well, if it's your first time, that is to be expected.
Still, part of the issue is that I am not quite sure what to make. Any ideas?

Fields.MenuText: How about animals or something else from nature?
Try to look for something that fits with your interests.
You could always sculpt me.

Fields.DialogueText: That could work. Jens specialized in natural scenes as well, and it's something I enjoy.
Good point – just like him, I need to find my own style.
I just might –but I'm already started, so perhaps another time.
In any case, don't give up. Actually, I think that you have a good mindset for sculpting – and art in general.
What do you mean?
Well, you have a patient attitude and attention to detail, so you always do your best on things.
Dziekuje ci. Thank you, Kapitan.
Don't mention it. You might want to clear away some of the extra debris, though.
I'll get on that right away. Well, after this next battle – there's going to be plenty more debris when we're through with this lot.
@BATTLE
Whew, those last shots came close!
Kapitan, are you okay?
I'm fine, Wicher. They're sure putting up a fight, aren't they?
Don't worry, I have you all covered.
Don't put yourself at too much risk though, Wicher. I don't want to lose you either.
I know, but I will put everything on the line to make sure everyone gets through this okay.
When you say "everyone," what you mean is everyone except you, right?
If it comes to that, It's a necessary sacrifice.
Still, I don't like you being so fatalistic. Why do you always put everyone else's wellbeing in front of your own?
Because, I'm afraid I'll lose them. Then I'll be all alone, having failed to protect anyone I care about.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think I – we – could live with losing you on the opposite end of things? You're a special person Wicher, so don't sell yourself short.
We'll all get through this war if we work together. You don't have to take all of the burden on yourself.
We can't save everyone, no matter how hard we try. We just have to do our best and live with our choices.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, I... you really think so? Thank you.
You're right, I need to be more of a team player in that regard.
Maybe, but that doesn't mean I have to like it.
Just know that we're here for you as well. You're not going to fail. I believe in you.
Dziekuje ci. Thank you, Kapitan.
So let's finish this, shall we?
Yes!
@BATTLE
Their ships are starting to fall back, Kapitan! There are only a few stragglers left.
@BATTLE
Well, that takes care of them for now. What are your thoughts on it, Wicher? Wicher?
Extra, extra, read all about it! Latest victory against the Morganas!
A newspaper?
One specially for the fleet. Want a copy?
Well, sure, but what's the point of having one all the way out here?
That's exactly why I decided to make one. Newspapers are excellent for literacy, you know – just look at Mariehamn – and we could really use one out here.
If you say so - but most of the events are things we witnessed ourselves.
Okay, it's a little rough at the moment, but I want to get everyone involved. That way, we'll have plenty of variety for readers.

Fields.MenuText: How did you get the release so quick? We just finished the fight.
Make sure you have some crosswords and other puzzles mixed in.
Do you have the weather printed in it?

Fields.DialogueText: I was taking notes during the brawl. It only slowed me down a little, and I was able to complete both tasks!
Don't worry. That was the first thing I worked on.
Yes, and the best you'll get in any paper. It's my specialty, after all.
I have to say, this is pretty good for a first edition.
Dziekuje ci - thank you. It will only get better in later issues.
Still, I have to say again, there's kind of a limited market for the news out here.
I know, but guests might want a copy of the day's newspaper in the morning.
Guests? What guests?
Um, I'll tell you later. Right now, I need to get these papers distributed.
All right, Kapitan. It's time for us to make some scenario plans for our upcoming battles?
Okay, but do you think that planning of this extent is necessary? We don't know exactly what the situation will be like when we actually encounter other Morganas.
No ba - but that's why we should make some plans for different potential scenarios.
You sure like to plan everything out ahead of time, don't you?
Of course! I hate being surprised at the last minute. Plans give you a sense of direction, so you don't get stressed out.
Or they stress you out even more when the plan goes wild.
That's just because the plan itself was not thought out properly. Hence, our current efforts to do things right.
Okay, okay, I get it. So what scenario should we work on?
Right now, we should plan ahead for the next time we are ambushed. So, what do you think we should do ahead of time to be ready?

Fields.MenuText: We should do training drills regularly.
We should map out the full interior and have diagrams available so we can get on deck quickly.
Probably straighten out the specifics on getting prepared for battle, so we don't fumble early on.

Fields.DialogueText: Good idea. It's a great way to stay in shape, too.
That would be excellent. It can sometimes be tricky remembering the way through the halls, can't it?
That would be useful.
There! Now we just need to write down the specific...
We'll need to wait for another time. We're being ambushed again!
I see. Remember to follow protocol.
Of course.
@BATTLE
So, Wicher, what was it you were saying about guests before?
Oh, it's just a little thought I had.
I'm all ears.
Okay. You see, I want to turn the fleet into a sort of resort.
A resort.
Tak. It will take a lot of work, but Gdynia used to be a little fishing port, and look at it now!
You're serious about this.
I am always serious about everything I do. And... it's a way to make this place more like home.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure how many people will be eager to vacation in a war zone.
Living spaces will be kind of cramped for guests, you know.
What about the library plan we were working on?

Fields.DialogueText: You'd be surprised at the risks people will take. And besides, I'll make sure I keep everyone safe.
That just means that we'll need to sell them on the other amenities and attractions.
Who says we can't do both? Each can help support the other's growth.
Okay, I guess we can try it out. We'll need to do a lot of renovations.
I know, but now that I have your permission, I can get down to business with things.
Great. Let me know if I can help with anything.
Of course. I could use your assistance with the planning – and with holding up the guard against unwelcome hotel crashers.
@BATTLE
Now then, since you are aware of the project, it's time to start planning it out.
I thought you'd say that. So where should we start?
Well, I am still figuring out some unique attractions to draw in tourists. So, for right now, I think we should focus on the overall amenities.
That's going to be a little difficult to provide on a warship.
We can still give it our best efforts, though. Frontier lodges are kind of spartan as well, but people are still willing to stay there, if the amenities and attractions are good enough.
You have a point about that. So what part of the guest treatment should we focus on?
Actually, I was wondering if you might have an idea.
Me?
Tak. I have never actually run a hotel before. Moreover, you have a lot of skill leading us, so I think you have the right qualities for managing things.
Thank you. This is a big honor.
You're welcome. I have full faith in you, Kapitan.
Let's see... how about this?

Fields.MenuText: We work on providing high-quality meals.
We offer artistic decor in their rooms.
We give them access to enthralling literature.

Fields.DialogueText: You just love my food, don't you, Kapitan?
I get it. I've been making some good strides as an artist, so we could use some of the older ones for decorations.
Excellent suggestion. It's always nice to read a good book before bed. And, we already have a library on board, so that helps.
Thank you for the suggestion, Kapitan. Dziekuje ci. I knew that I could count on you.
Well, that's natural. We make a great team, don't we?
We sure do.
By the way, what were some of the special attractions you had in mind? I know there's the waterfall, but what else?
I'll have to show you later – right now, these "guests" cannot wait.
@BATTLE
Kapitan, I fear we are vastly outnumbered!
@BATTLE
Well, that was rough. I've got aches on top of aches.
Maybe I can help with that, Kapitan.
How so?
Just hold still for a second.
What are you... oh, that feels good.
Do you like the massage? I've been reading up on some of the techniques, in preparation for opening a spa on the ship.
For the resort? That sounds like a feasible idea. A little to the right, please.
Got it. But... I had another motivation, too, I admit.
What's that?
Why, to help you and the others out here, of course. I want to do my best to support you, and this is one way to help everyone recover from these hard battles.
Thank you, Wicher. That is very thoughtful of you.
You're welcome. So, how am I doing so far?

Fields.MenuText: I feel better already.
Still a little tired, but less sore.
You're doing great, but don't tire yourself out, either.

Fields.DialogueText: Great, but don't overexert yourself just yet.
Understandable. These things take time.
Sorry, I just wanted to put all of my effort into helping you. I guess I could use some spa treatment as well.
Okay, I'm finished.
Thanks again for the massage, Wicher. It really helped me get back to normal.
Don't mention it. So, do you think it would work well at the resort?
Of course! You'll need to teach the techniques to more people, though.
Tak - I know, but it's a start, at least.
If we stick to the plan, I think we can end this battle quickly!
@BATTLE
Wicher, what's with all the smoke?
Cough... Captain... help!
Don't worry, I'm coming to save you.
Phew. Thank you for clearing away the smoke.
You're welcome. I know you hate getting exposed to it. What happened in here?
I was trying to brew Madeira-style wine.
... Things were on fire in here.
Well, this is a special sort of alcohol. It's created through oxidation.
You mean it has to be exposed directly to fire?
Tak. It is what makes the wine unique. I was trying to replicate it, but things didn't quite work out.

Fields.MenuText: Well, ignoring the fire, did the wine turn out okay?
It's all part of the learning process.
It's nice to see that you're trying new things.

Fields.DialogueText: Actually, it's not half bad.
I suppose you're right. It just takes time and practice.
You know me, I always enjoy a variety of cultural things.
Hey, why don't we have a toast with the surviving wine?
Good idea. What shall we toast to?
How about less smoke in the future?
Great! To less smoke!
Mmm! This is wonderful! Maybe we should have toasted to "less Morganas" instead.
Nice ski outfit there.
Dziekuje ci - you're too kind! Do you really like it?
I sure do. What are you planning to do with it, though? There isn't really a place to ski around here.
Not yet, at least.
Yes, not... what do you mean by that?
It's one of the additions I have in mind for the resort – a ski lodge.
How are we going to ski on a ship? We don't even have any snow!
I'm working on a way to fix that. We also need to find some areas to turn into the slopes.
And find a place to store the equipment. I think it will be a little crowded with the waterfall. Space *is* a factor.
Okay, it could use a little work. I still think it's workable.

Fields.MenuText: Just make sure the snow doesn't spread over the rest of the deck.
I'm just worried that the snow will melt too quickly with the ship's heat.
Why not settle for cross-country instead, given the shape of the ship?

Fields.DialogueText: I'll keep things under control, don't worry.
Good point. Even so, I think I can manage a good balance between the two ends of the spectrum.
Not a bad idea. Still, I like the idea of a ski jump.
I'm sorry that you don't exactly like the idea, Kapitan.
It's okay. I'm glad that you are putting a lot of thought into the resort idea.
There's one other advantage to having ski equipment on board, you know.
What's that?
The poles can make decent weapons, and we need every advantage we can to take on the Morganas!
@BATTLE
Kapitan, would you mind if I make a portrait of you?
Go right ahead.
Dziekuje ci - thank you. Now, hold still.
Got it. How are you doing with it?
Just a little longer and... got it!
Good, now I can move again.
Here is the sketch. What do you think of it?
Let's take a look. Oh, I see! It's...

Fields.MenuText: It's very accurate.
It's a little blurry, but still beautiful.
Very nice. Thank you for making it of me.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you! I tried to capture all of your physical details.
That's understandable. I was going for a more abstract approach. Still, I'm glad that you like it.
No need to thank me. I was elated that I could make a picture of you... I mean, since we're such good partners.
Anyways, you did a great job.
Dziekuje ci! I'm happy that I managed to get it right.
I had no doubt of that. You're such a remarkable artist in your own way, Wicher, that I would have been pleased no matter how you decided to go about the portrait.
Kapitan...
By the way, do you think you could teach me to be an artist? Then I could make a portrait for you as well.
That sounds great! I can start teaching you lessons right away – well, after we erase those Morganas from the scenery.
@BATTLE
Kiyah!
Wah! Watch it with that stick there, Wicher!
Come on, it was only a light tap.
Uh-huh. Um - slight tangent here: that looks like a fresh branch. Is it from a tree you planted?
Tak. A pussy willow. It's quite the tradition back in Poland.
Of course. Still, could you please avoid whacking everyone on board?
I am not hitting everyone. I have only hit you.
That makes me feel so much better.
I can give you a stick as well, if that helps.
No, thanks.
Just thought I'd offer.

Fields.MenuText: I hope that the tree is still doing well.
Just be careful not to hurt anyone with it.
I guess it's just a part of you that I'll have to live with. You have your own way of doing things.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry, I made sure that it was nice and healthy before I even thought of clipping off a branch.
You're right, I'll be more careful.
Thank you, Kapitan. That's what I like about you.
So, you have a personal tradition of whacking people on the head with these branches?
Well, sort of.
What do you mean by that?
Will you look at that! We have Morganas to take care of. I'd better go whack them– with a different kind of stick, that is.
@BATTLE
Brrr! Wicher, why's it so cold down here?
I'm just getting a new system put in.
A system for what? If this is about that ski slope again...
Nie, this is going to be a cold store.
Oh, you mean for storage?
Exactly. Particularly meats and other perishables that require cold temperatures.
Okay, that makes sense. Still, this is kind of over the top in regard to space, wouldn't you say?
I'd beg to differ – the one back in Gdynia is much larger.
So that's where you got the idea...
Plus, once we get the resort going, we will need to have a lot more supplies on hand.

Fields.MenuText: Just as long as you can get things to fit okay, go right ahead.
It's good that you are preparing for that scenario already.
Could you please make sure that the cold doesn't spread to the rest of the ship, though?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. I'll keep going with it.
Plan ahead! That's my motto.
Okay, but it's not that cold. Compared to some of the places I've been, this is like a sauna!
Well, at least this could be a solution to your skiing dilemma.
You mean do the skiing in here with the food?
Both require cold temperatures, so why not?
Hmm... I will need to rethink some of my blueprints, but this could work. Thank you for the suggestion, Kapitan.
Don't mention it. I'm just happy that you are finding ways to keep yourself busy and happy.
Well, it's also to help everyone. We have to be prepared for everything in this day and age.
You're right. Let's hope our stocks will last us through the coming fights, or at least, through the one that is about to happen now.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Hi, Wicher. What are you working on there?
I am trying to make my own paper.
Huh. That sounds tricky.
It is. Fortunately, I had the process explained to me in great detail at Vyborg, so I've already got a foot in the door.
That's good, but what got you interested in making it?
Books, of course! The newspaper and library are going to need plenty of paper, so I thought I would be inventive and make some of our own.
Great! How far have you gotten?
Five pages!
That's all?
Well, it's a taxing process. Especially with everything else I'm working on.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe it will work quicker if you mechanize the process.
We can work together to get this process done.
You're still getting the hang of it. I'm sure things will work out.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. I can get an apparatus in place a little later. I just like doing it personally as well.
You're right. We're all part of the same team out here, after all.
Dziekuje ci - thank you. I'm sure that I'll master this in no time.
It's pretty interesting. You wouldn't think that these thin little things take so much work.
You can say that again! For me, there is a sense of satisfaction in giving life to a material that in turn will give life to words for posterity.
Ever the philosopher, aren't you?
It's what I do best. If only we could also make paper out of the Morganas!
@BATTLE
Hey, Wicher, how are –?
Shh! Quiet!
What?
Careful or you'll scare them away.
Sorry. Scare who?
These butterflies. They found their way here and have made themselves at home in the garden.
Ah, I understand. Cute little fellows, aren't they?
No ba. Almost as pretty as a caterpillar.
I'm kind of surprised to see them all the way out here, though.
A lot of species find their way to islands by chance. They somehow manage to survive the trials of the sea until they find a safe haven and prosper.
That's kind of amazing, how they can find new homes like that.
Yes, and often they never see their old homes again.

Fields.MenuText: Does this mean we will have our own unique species of butterflies eventually?
Then again, most islands are not mobile.
Even so, they bring their own stories to their new homes, so that their old history lives on.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... Maybe, in a few decades.
You have a good point. I'm sure I'll find a way to return to Poland one day.
You're right. I have to look on the bright side. Our heritage will not be lost as long as I have a say in it!
Well, it looks like they have made themselves right at home. I'll pass the word not to disturb them.
Really? Thank you. They've gone through so much, I want this to be a sanctuary for them.
No problem. Though we'll have to work hard to protect them from the Morganas.
Same as always, then. We've yet to face true defeat, so let's do our best again!
@BATTLE
What's going on in here?
Oh, I'm making a few spa baths for the resort.
I see. Although, you might want to clean it up a little bit. There's mud all over the place!
That's because this particular unit is a mud bath, an all-natural, cure-all.
Interesting but make certain that it doesn't dirty up the rest of the water.
Not to worry, I have everything planned out.
That's good to know. You have a little bit of something for everyone, don't you?
Well, we all have our own tastes. A good variety helps keep everybody happy and gives them the chance to try new things.
You have a point there.
On that note, care to try it out?

Fields.MenuText: Sure, since it's something you like, it's bound to feel amazing.
Maybe later, I'm worried about getting my uniform dirty.
I'll give it a try, if I can also try out the regular baths afterwards.

Fields.DialogueText: That's sweet of you. Still, feel free to try things as you feel fit. After all, we all have our own views.
Okay, I look forward trying it out with you later.
That is perfectly reasonable. Both have their own virtues.
Just as long as none of it gets on my –
*SPLASH*
And, now, there's mud everywhere!
We'd both better clean ourselves up after that spill.
That can wait. I have a feeling that that was not a natural tidal wave.
Tak. You're right. With enough work, we can grind those monsters into muddy mush as well.
@BATTLE
Wicher, where are you?
In the garden over here.
Okay, got it. Amazing... you've really expanded your garden a lot since the beginning.
Well, once I got started, and became confident that I could protect it, I looked for ways to further develop it.
You certainly have done that. It has a very diverse yet peaceful feel to it.
That makes sense. I was inspired by the "Mon Repos" – "My Place of Rest."
Oh? Is it someplace you visited during your journeys?
Not in person, but I got to see pictures - it is an incredibly beautiful, English-style garden in Vyborg.
And now you're trying to replicate it.
To a degree. To be honest, much of the features of Mon Repos stem from the natural setting there. But what I love most is its sense of vibrancy, and that I can recapture here.

Fields.MenuText: You have really found your own place out here, haven't you?
Why did it get the name "My Place of Rest"?
The garden is incredible. You are a wonderful planner and caretaker.

Fields.DialogueText: Tak. I have. I do not know what will become of me and my homeland before we are through out here, but I can and will, at the very least, protect the new home I have made.
Officially, I think that it earned the name from the original owner, who made it to remember his wife. But really, I see it as a token of this being a garden of dreams.
Dziekuje ci - thank you. I hope that we can both spend much time here together.
Still, it is taxing trying to maintain the upkeep for everything out here.
Even so, you manage to get things done right in the end, so I have no doubt that the garden will continue to thrive.
You're right. I just wish that we could safeguard the whole world in the same manner.
All in good time. For now, let's make things a bit safer by getting rid of these nasty trespassers.
@BATTLE
Hi there! Working on the designs for the resort, I see?
No ba. I have lots of things planned.
Still, we're going to have to charge quite a bit for each of the guests if we want to make up for the resources we're spending for this.
We will? Are you sure?
Of course. Hotels are built for profit, after all.
I suppose you're right...
Wicher, what's wrong?
Well, I had other reasons for establishing the resort.
Like what?
For one, if this place becomes autonomous territory, it would be at least one place that refugees could find shelter.
Like those from Poland and other conquered states.
Exactly. Plus, I wanted to attract people here to the library, so they can be made aware of our stories.

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps we can do both, helping people in this time and turning more toward profit when things get better.
You have a very generous heart, Wicher.
Even so, a hotel works because the guests rotate in and out. Otherwise, we'll run out of room.

Fields.DialogueText: Dziekuje ci - thank you. That sounds like a reasonable approach.
I know, but sometimes I feel like all of my efforts come to naught in the end.
You're right. I need to be realistic about this.
Look, we can figure out a way to make things work. So let's not get too worried yet while we're still sketching things out.
Yes, together...
Something else bothering you?
I'll tell you later – after this battle.
@BATTLE
Kapitan! That was a direct hit! The tide is turning in our favor!
@BATTLE
We did it! Ready to celebrate, Wicher?
Sure, but first, could we go somewhere more private?
Sure. You seem so serious. Is something wrong?
I... want to thank you for everything that you've done for me.
It was nothing, really.
Oh, but it was! When I left home, I was so afraid, so unsure of what would happen. But you were there, always supporting me and offering new outlooks to problems.
We're a team. That's what we do for each other.
Tak. And I... have come to realize that I don't want our special relationship to end.
What do you mean?
Kapitan, how do I put this? I would like for you to remain with me... as a partner, not just a manager, for the resort indefinitely!
Wait, you're serious? Don't you think that, eventually, you will need to find someone with more experience in that area? I only know so much about running a hotel, let alone a resort!
I told you before, that I can't think of anyone who would be a better leader. So... will you consider staying? With me? For the prosperity of the resort, of course.
Of course. After all, with you fighting alongside me all this time, I can't think of anyone who would make a better partner.
Oh, Kapitan! You have made me so happy!!
Come on, then! The crew is waiting for us to celebrate!
I'm am with you, every step of the way.
